intro: Rhysolepis subtruncata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sandwort, is a small, flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and small, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pinkish flowers in early spring, which are typically borne on short, erect stems. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Rhysolepis subtruncata is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with showy blooms.
